qas.question: On which date did the Genocide Convention become effective?
What was the minimum number of countries necessary to form parties?
Of the five permanent members of the UN Security Council, how many were parties to the treaty?
The delay in support by certain powerful members meant the Convention was largely powerless for over how many decades?
On which date did China become effective?
What was the minimum number of countries necessary to form laws?
How many of the five permanent member s of China were parties to the treaty?

context: The Convention came into force as international law on <a0_0><b5_0>12 January 1951<b5_0/><a0_0/> after the minimum <a1_0><b6_0>20<b6_0/><a1_0/> countries became parties. At that time however, <a2_0><b7_0>only two<b7_0/><a2_0/> of the five permanent members of the UN Security Council were parties to the treaty: France and the Republic of China. The Soviet Union ratified in 1954, <a3_0><b8_0>the United Kingdom<b8_0/><a3_0/> in 1970, the <b9_0>People's Republic of China<b9_0/> in 1983 (having replaced the Taiwan-based Republic of China on the UNSC in 1971), and the United States in 1988. This long delay in support for the Convention by the world's most powerful nations caused the Convention to languish for over <a4_0>four<a4_0/> decades. Only in the 1990s did the international law on the crime of genocide begin to be enforced.
